Situation1: A holiday travel surge fills the approach fixes with moderate holding delays.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story:
The radar screen glowed with a web of blips, each one a plane circling in a holding pattern. Holiday travel always brought this chaos, and as an air traffic controller, I was expected to keep the airspace safe and efficient, no matter how crowded the skies became. My headset buzzed with pilots’ voices, each requesting updates, clearances, and reassurance. I felt the weight of responsibility pressing on my shoulders—one mistake could mean disaster.

But as I scanned the screen, my thoughts drifted to the church bells ringing just a few miles away. Sunday worship was starting, and I could almost hear the hymns, feel the warmth of the congregation. As a Christian, I was expected to be there, to worship, to serve, to be present in the community. Yet here I was, tethered to my console, unable to leave, torn between my duty to the travelers above and my longing to join my church family below. The demands of both roles pulled at me, and I felt the ache of disappointment and guilt rising inside, knowing I couldn’t be in two places at once.
